title: Daniel Crennan tops chief justice in pay stakes
text:
Crennan also has the Commonwealth DPP Sarah McNaughton ($554,220) covered. However, McNaughten can console herself with a top-four finish and the knowledge that she is paid slightly more than the other six High Court judges ($551,880).

Bar none: Solicitor-General Stephen Donaghue QC outside the High Court. AAP

However, Crennan falls some way short of the gold medallist – Solicitor-General Stephen Donaghue QC. The government's chief legal adviser and principal High Court advocate is on a base salary of $775.910.

That's the same mark as ASIC chair James Shipton. Curiously, Shipton and Crennan are paid more than ACCC chief Rod Sims ($581.940).

Still, it’s pretty good coin and not far off what Crennan would have taken home if he was still at the private bar as a relatively new silk (he was anointed in 2016).

Oops, forgot about that

The extra detail in the 2018-19 ASIC annual report was mandatory after The Treasury (Enhancing ASIC’s Capabilities) Act 2018 removed the regulator as a statutory agency. (Part of enhancing ASIC's capabilities was to give it more salary room/flexibility.)

As a statutory agency, it was a "prescribed authority" for the purposes of the Public Interest Disclosure (PID) Act, which is meant to protect whistleblowers.

Advertisement

However, the geniuses at Treasury forgot about that bit. So, from July 1 – when the Act took effect – until October 11 there was no PID safeguard for anyone who wanted to spill the beans on ASIC's inner workings.

On that day, Attorney-General Christian Porter quietly restored ASIC's status as a prescribed authority. He didn't say when staff were made aware of "ASIC’s inadvertent removal from the scope of the PID Act" but thankfully there were no sweaty palms. "No public interest disclosures were made during the period 1 July 2019 and 11 October 2019,'' said Porter.

Lucky 13 for bar's rising star

Barrister Renee Enbom has worked on several high-profile cases. Eddie Jim

Melbourne barrister Renee Enbom’s reputation as rising star was confirmed on Wednesday when Victoria Chief Justice Anne Ferguson announced a new batch of silks.

Enbom was junior to bar president Matt Collins QC for Rebel Wilson’s stoush with Bauer Media and is now going into bat for Victoria Police at the Lawyer X royal commission.

“Perfect for a young silk,” Collins told Hearsay. (He has a cruel streak.)

On a more serious note, Collins – who passes the baton to Wendy Harris QC next month – reckons the bar is near the tipping point when it comes to appointing women as silk. Of the 18 appointed this year, five were female.

“More than 40 per cent of barristers who have been at the Victorian Bar for 15 years and under are women. Most silks are appointed after about 15 to 20 years as a barrister [Ms Enbom took only 13], which means I have every expectation that the pool of women silk candidates in the next few years, at least at our bar, should start to approach parity with men.”
description: There are only two lawyers on the public purse who earn more than the High Court Chief Justice – and one of them is ASIC deputy chairman Daniel Crennan QC.
